title: Desktop Widget (clock, weather forecast, world timer ....)

description.text:
Update #2: Someone asked whether the body can be reshaped to host a node MCU. This doesn't work but a Wemos Mini fits into the housing. Therefore I added a tray that can hold this ESP8266 board. 
Update #1: Forum for exchange of widget app ideas and code  
I deal international and have a lot of those time and weather                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 widgets on my windows desktop. But windows rearrange them always so It's much better to have them in real on my desk.   
With a ESP8266 and a 128x64 OLED display you can build it for only around 5$! The ESP fetch the information from the internet by WLAN and the OLED display it - done   
Here I made a tiny, well looking housing for them. I had a simple, "BRAUN"-style design  in mind. But it the finish result doesn't remind a BRAUN device very much. For me it rather associates with the helmet of a star wars storm trooper. However it appears likely to me.   
For switching anything I made also a version with two push buttons but as this destroy the design I made a further version with a gesture sensor. This works perfect and doesn't impact the design but double the cost at least.  
For the hosting of the electronics there are two version as well. One with only OLED display and ESP 8266 (ESP-03) and one with an additional Arduino mini pro (ESP-01 in this case)

Printed without support on the highest resolution (0.2mm). Important to use more solid layers (I used 6 instead of 3). Sand, sand, sand acetone treatment (in my case 1,5 h) The electronics can be programmed as usual if you have the knowledge. Alternatively there are lot of codes in the internet when looking for: ESP8266 OLED SSD1306. For example the weather widget I found here: http://blog.squix.ch/2015/05/esp8266-projects-internet-connected.html I created a forum where ideas, hints, code, hardware information etc. can be exchanged: http://desktopwidget.forumfrei.com/

comments.text: Is there a full tutorial article or video on how to do this? This looks like a good introductory project to coding.

comments.text: You mean for the coding of the micro controller? No, there isn't a tutorial.

comments.author: radeon

comments.text: I want to be able to get the current time, date, sunrise and sunset times. Would I be able to get the time, date, sunrise, sunset times, using parts of your code, given Lat and Long?
comments.author: mariarti

comments.text: Yes you can. Please the code I use for the desktop widget II https://hackaday.io/project/11081-forex-display. The API I use there deliver based on the Lat and Long the current time as the sunset, sunrise and weather
comments.author: mariarti

comments.text:
What's the purpose of the Arduino, the buttons and the buzzer I see in your pictures? The code from http://blog.squix.ch/ runs on the ESP8266 without any buttons.
Are these for future use? Did you use any other program that takes advantage of the buttons?
comments.author: hackermagnet

comments.text: Yes, the buttons as the beeper are for future use. My original idea is to switch between different cities but I didn't wrote the code yet
comments.author: hackermagnet

comments.text: Thanks for your reply. I have printed the body and I tested some examples writen in LUA. I don't have experience in LUA and I want to write my own code on Arduino IDE. If I won't succeed I will use a pro mini but I would prefer to use only the ESP8266. I have a ESP-01 at the moment and I will order a ESP-07. With more GPIOs I'm thinking to create something more than a weather widget. Maybe a notification system with color leds when I receive an email and preview of received message on the screen (I think Pushover service is amazing for these purpose.)
comments.author: smily77

comments.text: The Arduino IDE works perfect. I recommend you to order the ESP-12E instead of the the ESP-07. It has more memory (Important for OTA - Over the air updates - capability), the better WiFi perception and and more GIOP's. As far I know there isn't a ESP-07E yet. The ESP-12E is a bit bigger but can be used in the widget if you stick it just behind the OLED display.
comments.author: hackermagnet

comments.text: tried your code on my spi, work really nice! ;)
comments.author: 3dpov

comments.text: For the pictures of the desktop widget I partly used a program of Dani Eichhorn (see bottom of the instruction section). He wrote an amazing version two of this program. Please check his comment on http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?13631-A-Little-3D-Printed-Weather-Widget-For-Your-Desktop
comments.author: smily77

comments.text: really want to make this, for my office desk, could this be made to be battery powered, 1x aa or 1x aaa would be best, hey even a 12v door bell battery.
comments.author: JHilton

comments.text: I assume a battery wouldn't last very long and as it is thought to have it on the desk I made it to be supplied from the PC. I made a Mini-USB connector for power supply on the back that it can be connected to a free USB jack on the computer. I added a picture from the back side that you can see what I mean. By the way the header above the Mini-USB jack is for programming the ESP8266-03. (1. VCC, 2. TX, 3. RX, 4.GND, 5. GPIO0, 6. Reset
comments.author: JHilton

comments.text: So where are the schematics, I see an 8 pin IC in the pic and a piezo Whats that for?
comments.author: chappy1978

comments.text: What you see is a ESP8266-03 board which is a complete Wifi-read controller board (you'll get it for 3-4 USD at Ebay or a China distributor). I have a buzzer two switches against ground and of course the I2C OLED display in the sample housing.
comments.author: chappy1978

comments.text: Fantastic!
comments.author: hsinhung

comments.text: This is incredibly cool! Do you have a link for the code that's running on the ESP8266? I might make one myself, if so. Keep up the great work!!

comments.text: I made a forum where ideas and code can be exchanged: http://desktopwidget.forumfrei.com/ Currently you can find here the code for the weather and clock examples, Others will follow
comments.author: KenWilkinson62

author: smily77

description.text: These are the 3D parts I designed for a jewelry rack for a corner of our closet. The wood frame holds 12"x18" panels of floral foam which can hold earrings with wire loops, or can take pins for other items. The staggered hooks are for necklaces.

title: Weekly cup nr18, thanks to Anne Wagemakers for the graphic...

description.text:
Weekly cup nr18, thanks to Anne Wagemakers for the graphic...
This year I [will] upload a new cup every week. Sometimes with patterns made by other graphic designers...

Download, slice and print. This one was sliced with cura with "joris" activated in the expert settings at a pretty low resolution 0,25mm layer height. 1mm outer wall, 0,8mm nozzle, 1,2mm bottom thickness, no top.
print time: 23 minutes, 57 seconds see also:
www.rooiejoris.nl
facebook.com/europerminutedesign

comments.text:
I scaled and printed this at 60%, then further scaled it on the Z axis to 120%, and it fits snugly and works perfectly on my iPad Air 2 in both orientations. It has a 2mm case. Including the case, the total width of ithe iPad is 9.7mm. If I printed it again I might make it 65% or thereabouts so it's not as snug. But yeah, I think 100% is way too big for any tablet.
Thanks.

comments.text: I doubt that this will achieve a stable flight as all the weight is in the bottom of it.  Try running some simulations using Rocsim.  I would just hate for someone to make it and loose it first flight.  You might try adding some epoxy and fishing weights to the nose cone but I don't know if that would be enough to stabilize it.

description.text: This is a blank cover plate to fill the opening where the power mirror control goes on the center console of a 1989-1994 (S13) Nissan 240SX. This model is intended to be 3D printed. I created this to replace the broken one on my car, and also to create a mounting spot for a mini trackball to control the Raspberry Pi car entertainment system that I'm designing. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/di3PrxQmcM8
This model was generated from measurements that I took from the broken part it is intended to replace.  It is intended to simply snap into the hole it fills on the center console.

title: Glass Bed Holder for 180mm Glass on 220mm Heat bed

description.text: This is cut out for a 180mm glass on a 220mm round bed.  Glass holder.

I have a 220mm round heat bed, but I have only a 180mm round glass, so I needed a way to hold the glass centered and it was too far away to use the binder clip technique - So I made a little brace.  
This is cut out for a 180mm glass on a 220mm round bed.  i have 6 holes drilled in mine, 3 for mounting and the other 3 are open, so I put this in with a 10mm bolt - works great.  I found that the 25mm size was a little tight, so I made the 20mm sized one.  you can use a combination of these to make it fit on your round bed.  
Hope it helps someone

author: jnofsinger

title: Iphone 6 and 6 plus sun and sand beach protector

description.text:
My daughter asked me to print something to protect her iphone 6 plus from the sun and sand when she went on vacation to the beach. (now also known as: iPhone 6 Plus Sun Shade) These items are designed to keep the iphone off the hot sand and shield it from the sun while still allowing air to pass through and cool it. Apparently it worked quite well, here is my daughter's report:
"Hi, Dad -
As promised, I tried the iPhone 6 Plus Sun Shade (my new name for the thing in the picture that you printed, below) at the pool today. The sun was very hot, clear sky at the time and temperature in the upper 80s or low 90s. The sun shade effectively kept my iPhone 6 Plus cool for a full hour. It was sitting on a table in the sun shade below (see photo). When I took the phone out of the sun shade, it was regular temperature. From past experience, when I left my phone exposed in the hot sun for 10-15 minutes, it became so hot that the iPhone automatically powered itself off due to the hot temperature." "Yep, worked like a charm!" Files are provided for both the Iphone 6 and Iphone 6 plus. The Iphone 6 plus can fit in the Iphone 6 protector, but it has to be twisted in from the side. The Iphone 6 plus should fit easily in the Iphone 6 plus file, but it's max print dimension is 202 mm. The dimensions for assemblies and parts are shown in files in the pictures

print one set of four posts using file: iphone_thermal_shield_posts_150531e.stl  
Print 2 base parts using one of the following files:  
"iphone_6_thermal_shield_base_150531e.stl" for the Iphone 6 (or snug for Iphone 6 plus)  
"iphone_6_plus_thermal_shield_base_150531e.stl" for the Iphone 6 plus with plenty of room  
Glue the 4 posts into the two base parts using acetone or your favorite glue. 
Science Trivia: the purpose of all the holes and honeycomb is to: reduce conduction heating, allow for better air flow to cool the plastic in contact with the phone (convection cooling) and to reduce and block infrared radiation heating .

It is a small-size funfair big wheel.  
Clara Gómez

Some of the models have to be printed several times. In the following, I tell the number of prints for each one ejes: once (the base was just used as support material because of the printer).
noria2_techo: it is the ceiling of each of the cabins. The maximum is 12, in my case I printed 6.
noria2_base: it is the base of each cabin (the same as for the ceilings).
noriaEjesCentro: it is the center of the wheel, where all the radii are assembled. You should print two.
radios: each of them is a radius, with the corresponding section of the wheel. You should print 12 for each wheel, so 24.
noriaPie1 and noriaPie2: these are the base of the big wheel. You should print one of each.
soporte1 and soporte2: these pieces form the support of the wheel. You should print two of soporte1 and four of soporte2.

author: Flakk

description.text:
3D print two "2d" pieces to make one 3d Christmas Tree.
I designed this and gave them away.

These are great for sailing, boating, canoeing, etc. Anytime you have a lot of ropes for securing things to cleats but need a way to make quick adjustments. These things cost $10-$20 online (plus shipping). Using this model, all you need are some 1/8" nuts/bolts/washers and/or screws.

These have not been tested or printed at all yet. There are a few known problems: 1) there is no spring action, so they will only lock on a rope using its own tension. 2) two hands may be required to make them lock (with one hand holding the rope down and a thumb applying pressure with the cleats against the rope. 3) they won't be as strong and durable as commercial cam cleats, so they shouldn't be used for life-critical applications. At this point, they are just a fun project for experimentation. 4) I didn't use precise measurements for the bolt cavities on the bottom of the base, so those could be improved.

author: CrapolaDesign

description.text: sketchup pro 2015

An honorary thank you medal for our Seneca 7 bike team "mule" who rode the whole distance solely to provide logistical support. (Just imagine Donkey is a mule.) Medal design traced from a photograph in Inkscape, paths converted to line segments with Flatten Path extension, exported to DXF, imported/extruded/exported to STL with OpenSCAD. (The Seneca 7 medal design is, of course, property of the Seneca 7.) Medal and Donkey models combined with Meshmixer. Attempted to use Inflate tool to fill in mouth a bit for easier printing. Decimated to reduce polygon count with Meshlab.

White PLA. Slic3r settings: 0.3 mm layer height. 3 perimeters. 4 top/bottom layers. 10% line infill. Supports enabled at 18° with default settings (supports lower jaw but roof of mouth is unsupported and a bit scribbly).

title: Prusa i3 bed probe - induction switch parts

description.text: I make robots for Marginally Clever. Your support lets me take the risks so you don't have to. In theory, the 3d printer can probe the print bed and get a perfect first layer without the user having to endlessly recalibrate. In a previous thing I tried a switch on a servo arm: the arm lowers the switch, probes the bed, and then retracts the switch. In practice this solution was bad. the probed values were inconsistent, and the software thought the bed was on a crazy angle that didn't match reality. Now I'm trying an induction switch. It doesn't have to touch the bed, it doesn't have to move, and so the probe results should be more consistent.

• Used one LJ12A3-4-Z/BY Inductive Proximity Sensor from Marginally Clever.
  • Printed this part.
  • Attached the mount to the side of the extruder head (see photo)
  • Altered my Marlin configure.h by following various instructions 1, 2 and using some common sense.
  • Don't skip testing!

title: Nexus 5 car cradle with GoPro mount

description.text: Nexus 5 cell phone cradle style car holder mounted on GoPro mount. The cradle has slider for micro usb connector that plugs in easily without the need to get the orientation right each time. Youtube video of using the cradle: https://youtu.be/0HdSp0rJrAc

The cradle is designed to prints on FFF 3D printer without support. Depending on your 3D print software you might need to disable support for the bridge over the micro USB power plug.  
I left 8mm opening for 3.5mm audio jack. That might not be enough for all jacks. If you need the wider opening, let me know and I'll update the STL files.  
The power slide goes inside a rail on the right side of the cradle. I found it useful to prevent the slide from getting all the way out. To do so there are 3 holes on the back of the slide. You can screw 3mm screw that would keep the slide from getting off completely.

author: yuppchukno

title: Drill powered tumbler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a rock tumbler powered by a drill dedicated to smoothing up small parts that require no stair effect.  
It runs on my variable speed drill but due to some side effects (a woman's disapproval) i couldn't really test it more than 15 minutes.

For this you'll need :
  • 2 4mm aluminium or steel rods, one longer than the other (for the drill)
  • 4 M3x8mm bolts
  • 4 office rubber bands
  • 1 drill with variable speed
  • 1 "support" part
  • 4 "rouleau" parts
  • 3 "agitateur" parts
    • Put a bolt in each side hole on each wheel, than install the rubber bands as you can (i used a 1.5mm allen key to keep them in place and pull them quite hard together to ensure they won't move). Put the wheels on the support, insert the rods and use a 2.5mm allen key to secure them in place by screwing the 3x8mm bolts. Glue with epoxy the "agitateur" parts inside a can. Find some kind of support to ensure the system is aligned with your drill and voilà ! you can now fill your can with medium and try to run your new tumbler. Now you notice that nothing is planned to avoid that can to move and jump out of the support. I know that and that's why it's a work in progress. You can still use something heavy on each side of the can for the moment. Don't forget to give me backup, cause i need to convince my wife the noise it makes is really worth it !

This is a mount for the V4 version of the HoryzonHD Camera from FoxTechFPV.com.   
The first version has larger holes and is narrower. It will grip the camera and hold it a the angle set.   
The small hole mount allows the camera to easily tilt up and down and can be used as part of a mount with a servo to control the tilt remotely.   
NOTE: Make sure to smooth the parts of the piece that will contact the camera since it's easy to rub off the black rubberized coating on the outside of the camera.  
The included scad files have a section at the top with all the variables for the size of the mount and will allow you to adjusted the mount size as needed. It should be easy to reuse for other cameras or devices.  
Also this is first thing I've ever made using any kind of 3D modeling or CAD software. My 3D printer isn't all that dialed in. So any feed back would be appreciated.

remixed_from.author: Dave855
remixed_from.title: Far Vew 5.8 Ghz 5 Turn RHCP Helical V2

description.text: There are several good 5.8 GHz helical antennas available already, but I wanted one that offered full protection for the wire, was compact and easy to print and did not require using glue for assembly. My design consists of two items that are held together with a single screw. It can simply not get any simpler. I have also made a 7 turn version of the antenna. That one may be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2144979 There are both left and right hand polarized versions of the former and the wire holder. Make sure to print the version you need. The antenna is inspired by Dave855's designs. I have used his former and parts of his wire holders mixed into my version.

• The reflector is only a template. Print it and use it to produce a reflector out of PCB material or copper. If you use a PCB, the copper surface must be turned forward, i.e. be the side that the wire holder is mounted to.
  • Insert the antenna connector in the out-most hole of the reflector and cut the wire 5-6 mm above the surface.
  • Fan out the outer isolation of the antenna wire and solder it to the reflector. There is a picture of this step in the process to make it easy to see what I mean.
  • Paint or lacquer the reflector to make it fingerprint proof. This step is purely esthetical and may be skipped.
  • Print the holder and the former.
  • Use the wire former to create a wire spiral.
  • Thread the wire on the holder and cut it to length in place.
  • Use an M3 screw and nut to fasten the holder to the reflector.
  • The last step is soldering the main wire and the antenna center wire together. To achieve the best results possible the connection to the antenna wire is very important. The main wire should be in parallel with the reflector board for the last 4 mm of it´s length. This section of the wire should be located 2 mm from the surface of the reflector (thanks to Dave855 for the information)

author: GuardianKnight83

title: X Y Z  Jacks for Mostly Printed CNC / Multitool

description.text:
This is an add on to the "Mostly Printed CNC / Multitool" which is a really nice design.  
I found that the cat 5e jack modules from Home Depot (CE Tech model 5025-WH) fit nicely in the end of the EMT conduit with a bit of preparation. They make for a very clean XY and Z connection that can be unplugged from the controller.  
I think this may work in conjunction with the drag chain mod but have not looked too closely at it yet.

First file the inside of the EMT to remove any burr especially if a pipe cutter was used to cut it. Use a utility knife to carve off about 11mm of bottom corners of the module's body. Carefully carve off the same length but shallower from the "dust cover". Trim off more from the bottom until the module with the cover on slides into the EMT end snugly.  
Drill a 1/4" hole in the top front of the dust cover and snip through from the front to the hole to make a U ( or D) shaped slot. Wire the opposite side stepper to the push pins in the jack. I used the solid color jacks for one stepper and the striped ones for the other stepper then paralleled them at the RAMPS side.  
The wires for the stepper on the same side as the jack should be encased in mesh wire guard. Route it through the narrow slot between the stepper mount plate and the EMT end then route it through the U shaped slot you cut in the dust cover. Finally snap the dust cover on and push the jack into the EMT end.  
My jacks are so snug that I did not need any glue and they can still be removed. I used 0.1" crimp connectors to go from the steppers to the jack's push pins so everything is easily removeable and all is hidden in the EMT tube.

title: 2015 Jeep Cherokee Garbage Bag Holder - Cup Insert

description.text:
In my previous car I could take a plastic shopping bag and wrap it around my shifter to hold and let the bag hang down the passenger side, but being that the shifter is on the drivers side of my new Grand Cherokee, I was using a water bottle in the top cup holder to hold the bag.  I designed this insert to hold the bag, all the while allowing for a bottle to be placed into the cup holder.  
I printed at .2 layer height, 20% infill and support with a clear PLA.  I am sure it could be designed better to print without support (larger filets would eliminate the need for support), and I may post a better version soon.  It was a snug fit into the cup holder, but did not require any force to insert it.  
Good luck and enjoy!

comments.text: Although it is a bit tight (needed sanding to fit in the cup holder) - it works quite well! Do not need to use any support material.
comments.author: Richard2112

comments.text: Thanks Richard!  Yes, it is tight... but it's funny, about a week later (without any touch up of the print), it fit much better all on its own.  And during the winter, it was too lose.  It almost needs to be sized down just a little bit, with spring tabs to keep it snug.  That is for another day when I have free time again.  I am also going to work on an iPhone holder for my cup holder.  As much as I love the Navi in my Jeep, Google maps always takes me a better route... so I find I leave my iPhone in the cup holder so I can see where it wants to take me.  I know I could put it on the window or mount it on a vent... but it's too hard to see it when it's that far away... and I want quick access in case I need to look at map details.  Any how... thanks for the reply and I hope you enjoy!
comments.author: Richard2112

description.text:
This caddy was designed as a place to keep my Apple
Watch band collection. I designed it from scratch using Tinkercad. I now have 3 different bands for my Apple Watch, with more to come, so I was in need of a way to store and organize them. I searched for existing solutions but to no avail, so I decided to create something.

Print all of the components and then assemble them.  You will need all parts, which I have set up as two separate prints (my printer isn't large enough to do it all at once.)  Total print time was 5 hours for PLA at .2 mm on my very slow printer.

Picked up a pair of old "Rollerblade" in-line skates at a garage sale for $2.  Removed the axles, wheels, and bearings and designed this filament spool holder from the parts.  
I've included the SCAD file just in case you got a different pair of skates...  
Note:  This thing used axles and bearings from only one skate ($1 total hardware cost). I've got enough left to make another set.

• Purchase pair of in-line skates at garage sale (cheaper is better).
  • Remove axles from one skate shoe (four axles).
  • Remove bearings from the four wheels (eight bearings).
  • Print 4 plates (see STL file)
  • Use 2 plates, 2 axles, and 4 bearings for each holder.
  • Save other skate for your next filament spool holder....
    • Note: This thing is designed around 608ZZ bearings and Rollerblade 8mm axles (~36mm long). If you can't find similar used skates, you may need to buy additional hardware or adjust the thing (SCAD file included). Good luck!

author: marmoset

title: USS John Paul Jones (DDG-53), USS Halsey (DDG-97)

description.text:
USS John Paul Jones (DDG-53) is the third Arleigh Burke-class Guided Missile Destroyer and the first ship of the class homeported on the west coast. She is named after American Revolutionary War Naval Captain John Paul Jones. She was built at Bath Iron Works in Bath, Maine. The ship is currently part of Destroyer Squadron 23, and administratively reports to Commander, Naval Surface Forces Pacific.  
USS Halsey (DDG-97) is an Arleigh Burke-class guided missile destroyer in the United States Navy.Halsey is named in honor of Fleet Admiral William Frederick "Bull" Halsey Jr. Halsey was commissioned 30 July 2005 at Naval Air Station North Island, Coronado, California, under commanding officer Commander James L. Autrey.

This is a filament guide for the Twoup printer. The clip is designed to grab the top rail which measures, 40mm x 6mm. Made one, had trouble with delamination around the hole. Here is an 8mm Rod Block Pillow Mount for use in fastening guide rods for use in CNC applications.  It is specifically tailored for use with 80/20 aluminum extruded framing, but can be mounted onto anything.
The part mounting holes can accept 6mm bolt hardware, and there is a single 3mm x 22mm screw (with nut pocket) that is used to tighten the user's 8mm rod in place.  The mount's overall size is about 53mm L x 20mm W x 34mm H and the 8mm rod (center) is spaced 21mm above the mount's base.

Printing with your favorite SkeinForge settings will work fine with this object.  I have printed this object rafted on the stock MB platform and  raftless on the HBP without issues.  Setting INFILL DENSITY in SF's FILL menu to 0.25 printed the mount plenty strong to support a 400mm rod very solidly with a rod mount on each end.
The mount requires very little post-printing work.  I used an X-Acto knife to clean out the part's 6mm base mounting holes and the slotted 8mm rod hole.  The 3mm rod griping hole and 3mm nut pocket, I just worked the screw and nut into place without much else.  You might find that running a 3mm drill bit through the hole will make the assembly process a little easier.

Tubular propeller container, great for keeping 7", 8", 9", 10", or (up to) 11" propellers together and safe during transport! The taller tube fits inside the smaller tube; it's a snug fit, but it should fit together and create a small amount of vacuum when you pull them apart.
  • Taller tube is 160mm high with a 55mm interior diameter
  • shorter tube is 150mm high with a 58mm interior diameter
    • I've been using these for a few days now, and find these:
  • fit great (props rest with little wiggle room)
  • close snugly (they don't pop open during transport!)
  • actually protect props from damage! (they don't take HUNDREDS of pounds of weight, but they prevent heavy gear in a bag/pile from bending props!)

Best slicing settings are always going to depend on your printer; I print primarially PLA with a 0.4mm nozzle with the following slicer config: http://pastebin.com/j31P7hc9 You may need to try printing the first ~15-20mm of each tube and trying to see if they fit together; if they don't: check your printer calibration! (there's ~0.5mm tolerance between parts which should allow for a fairly snug fit at ~1.1 extrusion multiplier. If you find they are too loose try to increase your extrusion multiplier, if too tight reduce appropriately!)
Print with 0.2 mm Layer without support

I build various multi-rotors; I've been building various H-Quads for a while and have been watching out for "wide" legs that are:
  • Light weight (~20G printed in PLA)
  • reusable (they bounce!)
  • tough (they come off in crashes, but I have not reprinted them in months!)
  • easy to print (these do take a bit of care, due to the open spans!)
    • I've been using these legs on a modified Dart 400 flipped upside down swinging 10" props. Lots of room for a Gopro in the front, and a blast to boot around with! NOTE: This does take some care to print; see the instructions!

Best slicing settings are always going to depend on your printer; I print primarially PLA with a 0.4mm nozzle with the following slicer config: http://pastebin.com/j31P7hc9 This model is a little tricky; as there is an open-span bridge in some areas. I find adding a fan (LOW speed, low airflow) helps get the bridges started.

description.text: I have a Boosted Board for getting around town, and I wanted a way to keep all of the various accessory pieces neatly organized. This is what I came up with. This accessory plate holds the battery charger with a separate clip for the charger's barrel plug, a Unit skateboard tool, and has a peg to hang the hand remote from assuming a wrist strap is being used. Everything I need is right where I can find it, and kept out of sight beneath the board when it's on the hangar.

The plate is approximately 200 mm square, so a large volume printer is required. I produced mine on a LulzBot TAZ5. An Ultimaker would also do, or maybe one of the new MB Replicators. I printed in ABS with 10% infill, but the charger doesn't get particularly hot, so PLA would do just fine as well. Many of the structures have overhang, so printing with support is a must. I put four screw holes in the design for symmetry, but honestly the charger is not that heavy, so one could get away with only using two. That said, I recommend using plastic drywall anchors unless it's being screwed directly to a stud.

"Sodder" for you Americans *Not yet printed, and completely untested. Always stuck without a way to reliably join wires?
wish you had something on you at all times?
I do - and thus this design was born. You will need a very long 3mm bolt and nut to suit Repeat - not yet printed! Three trays are included as well as a belt holster.
A jet lighter tray
A solder reel tray
A parts/tape reel tray
Mini tape reel
*Belt holster Trays are designed to be removable as a single unit and then laid out at the site of repair. I use such a lighter for making emergency connections, where a soldering iron is not readily available. There is a small tape reel to suit 19mm Nitto insulation tape.
Coming soon - a jig to wind the tape onto the spool. I'll add different size trays etc later, and I've included source filed for you to mod at your lesuire.

description.text:
Protective case with sliding cover for a Minim OSD v1.1 board. Features include:
  • Hole in cover for access to reset button
  • Ground pin indicator on the cover for the video pins
  • Video in (vertical slot) and video out (circle) indicators on the end of the case
    • There are 2 stl file versions of the case bottom - one has a slot at the video terminal ends to allow optional voltage and current sensor wires to pass through.

Print and use!  
You may have to clean out the grooves in the side of the case bottom to allow the top to easily slide in.  
If you use the optional voltage and current sensor connections/wires you can use the slot version of the case bottom to pass the wires through.  You should knot the wires inside the case for strain relief (so pulling of the wires doesn't stress the fragile solder joints).  The pics show how I configured mine.  I also hot glued the wires to a few places on the board for further support/strain relief.

author: multirotorshop

description.text:
The Prusa i3 Rework evolve in revision 1.5 !! eMotion Tech realized several improvements:
  • A new extruder with the following features :
    -- 1.75 mm filament compatible
    -- light, ergonomic and compact
    -- inductive auto-leveling probe
    -- automatic print cooling
  • Leadscrew Z (diameter 8mm / pitch 2mm) axis insuring faster and accurate movements
  • Relocating the X and Y axis endstops to simplify the wiring
  • Modification of the « Z top Left » and « Z top Right » for more rigidity
  • Belt tensioner added on the axis X
  • All bearings are now 624ZZ: Miniaturization of the « Y Idler » to support a 624 ball bearing.
    • All resources are on our website, you will find more information in the instruction section. All improvements are compatible with the Prusa i3 Rework 1.0
    Enjoy!

Assembly instructions are on our website:
  • In English :
    The documentation in the Prusa_i3_rework/Documentation
  • En Français :
    Vous trouverez notre documentation dans la section "Prusa_i3_rework/Documentation"
    Ainsi que les fichiers dans la section Prusa_i3_Rework
    • All files (STL and STEP) are on our website http://www.reprap-3d-printer.com/download-center

comments.author: EPatt

comments.text:
Hello, I'm no expert in Makerfarm Prusa i3 but from what I saw the design is quite different from our Rework version. If you want to transform your printer I believe you will have to unmount quite a lot of parts until you can find the compatibility which is maybe not the best option (but at least really instructive and fun :) ). I think if you only want to replace the extruder you better design an adaptation part between the X carriage and our rev1.5 extruder.
I hope I gave you some leads :)

author: MarkusA380

title: Backing Plates for a Skateboard Holder

description.text: I found a great design for a skateboard holder that I wanted to use, but because of the thickness of the wheels on my board they would still rest against the wall when on the hook. These two plates are my solution to that problem. The hook plate is designed to mate with the holder designed linked above. The rest plate was designed simply to be a place for the lower set of wheels to rest on. NOTE: The plates are twelve inches wide, so a large volume printer is required for this design.

The parts were printed in ABS, with 10% infill. PLA would also suffice. The plates are twelve inches wide, so a large volume printer is required. I produced these on a LulzBot TAZ5, and even then I had to rotate the part to sit on the build plate at an approximately 45 degree angle in order for it to fit inside the build volume. The hook plate has an inset designed to accept the skateboard hook design I printed out. Using the rest plate for both the top and bottom could work too, and would yield another 1/4" clearance for the hook. I highly recommend the using of drywall anchors when installing these, especially for the hook.

Fed up with the cover over your trailer becoming a pond in the rain? I was. You probably weren't. I made this ridged peak to go on my trailer. It creates a little rake to the roof and stops the water from pooling. These joints are designed to be an easy push fit with 21.5mm waste pipe available from all good UK plumbers (such as http://www.screwfix.com/p/overflow-waste-pipe-21-5mm-10-x-3m-pack-of-10/18180). The OpenSCAD file is present so that you can tweak the dimensions. The edge pieces simple slide on to the side of the trailer. The ridge pieces have a down pointing prong so that you can prop the whole thing up with more pipe if you choose, but I haven't found it necessary. Print at 15% infill without support.

comments.text: Oh wow, the v2 changes look incredible! I cannot wait until I can start printing this tomorrow, and I will SURELY post photos once I have it assembled! Zero, you did an amazing job with this.
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text: I'm sorry to report I had problems that prevented me from printing it. I have only loaded the body so far, but in every single slicer I try I am unable to slice it correctly due to numerous geometry errors. Specifically, it look like you may have modeled parts of the guitar separately and then combined them into a single grouping, but doing that isn't the same thing as making a single-walled manifold object. So far Cura, Slic3r, MatterControl, and Meshmixer have all choked on the file. Meshmixer in particular was very funny for having so many error pointers on the screen that I could barely see the guitar!  ;)
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text:
Hi,
sorry for the delay to reply!
It's strange, because i generate the g.code with CURA in 2.7 scale without problem... can you upload a screen of problem in Cura?
thank you!
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text: This is very nice! The body in particular is remarkably detailed, which is not seen in your print. That said, there is TOO much detail in certain areas to print properly, such as the severe overhangs of the bridge pieces (and of course the vibrato bar) which make it nearly impossible to print cleanly. Would you be interested in doing a somewhat simplified version that eliminates major overhangs, separates some of the components to be printed (such as the vibrato bar and the entire neck), and adds the usual Strat radius to the neck and fretboard?
comments.author: donstratton

remixed_from.author: tinkerings
remixed_from.title: PSMD (Pololu Stepper Motor Driver) Triple Axis Driver

title: PSMD (Pololu Stepper Motor Driver) Triple Axis Remix

description.text: Looking for ways to rebuild my two cupcakes in the search of the uber-cupcake, I stumbled on tinkerings' hybrid pololu / makerbot stepper driver. This thing is awesome and I had to have one. But looking at it closer I thought the trace routing could be a bit better with larger traces, tighter tolerances, and I felt it needed a little more power. So I rerouted the board, brought everything up to the top layer (dip switches would be worlds easier to adjust without taking the board off the bot), changed all the surface mount parts to 0805, and added an ATX-4 connector for a little more amperage. I also removed three of the endstop connections (because who really needs six?) to reduce the size of the board even more. Now its only a tiny bit bigger than the existing makerbot stepper drivers. With the right capacitors I still think it gets pretty good airflow under the drivers... these A4983 drivers rock and don't get too hot on the makerbot. Update: Everything works like a charm! The images show the cupcake after installation and even though my wiring is not fully done it makes a huge difference in the tidiness of the electronics. If my x carriage wasn't acting up the bot would be much quieter... the extruder motor is louder than the steppers. Update: Make sure that the belt tension is adjusted properly, as in looser than you think should even work - this was my problem with the x carriage. Then you need to dial back the current using the trimpot on the pololus until the motors move smoothly and quietly. Properly adjusted this thing is as quiet, well, as quiet as a resonant plywood box can be.

Update: This board has been built, tested, and approved by monkeys. I do not plan to make kits myself so if that is something you want to do then knock yourself out. The total approximate cost for this entire board is about $75 out the door if you choose to make one. Thats not bad and of course an economy of scale kicks in if you want to make a batch of them. To put the parts together, you can order the PCB from BatchPCB http://batchpcb.com/index.php/Upload or any board house of your choice. After creating an account, all you need to do is upload the attached zip file containing all of the processed gerber files. This has passed DRC and is a proven design. Just upload and order one. The files should also work fine through other vendors as well. For example, you could get about 20 of these for $100 through Gold Phoenix http://www.goldphoenixpcb.biz/special_price.php. For parts, this thing has been saved as a project at Mouser http://www.mouser.com:80/ProjectManager/ProjectDetail.aspx?AccessID=f46921ee6f. You should be able to order all the little parts there although I would add a handful of extra resistors just in case you loose one (and it happens). Finally you will need from Pololu, three A4983 stepper drivers http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1201 and six 8-pin female headers http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1018. These pins worked but required a little filing to get them to fit side by side. One long continuous strip of 24pins for each side would be better if you can find them. To put it together, start with the small parts like resistors and LEDs first and work up to the bigger things saving the through hole parts like sockets until the end. It was easier for me to solder the electrolytic capacitors before doing the dip switches but YMMV. Soldering these things is not too hard, just take your time. I find it easiest to put a little solder on one pad and then slide the part into the solder puddle using tweezers and then let go. When the solder is cool, solder the other pad. When its all put together be sure to plug the pololu drivers the right way around. The current adjusting potentiometer should be closest to the 4 pin end stop connectors. This would be up if looking at the text as right reading or down if you mount the board like I did in the photos. Note: The four pin molex power connector on this driver board is for 12volts only. This should be the connector on your power supply with 2 yellow and 2 black wires and not part of the 24 pin connector that plugs into the motherboard. Once its up and running you need to use the machines.xml file worked up by tinkerin.gs posted below for convenience and choose Driver â†’ Cupcake CNC (with 1/16th step Pololu Driver). This file should be updated when I get around to it. The last thing to do is adjust the current trimpots to get the motors moving each axis without overheating the drivers. Starting completely counter clockwise (with the trimpot pointing up) turn the trimpot until the axes are moving properly. With the motors eneabled in the control panel, you should not be able to move any of the axes by hand. If it skips, the current needs to be increased. And thats it! I hope this is helpful to someone out there. Cheers!

comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: The board runs somewhat independently of the rest of the electronics so it should work fine. Although I believe the cables are a little different for the stepper drivers that are a part of the mk3 as opposed to the mk4. (This one uses the 10pin mk3 style.) Im certain Ive seen a topic somewhere about using the mk3 drivers with the mk4 mainboard or vice versa that you could look into. This board does not have the fourth driver on it so you would still need an fourth stepper driver for the extruder. Microstepping isnt important for the extruder (in fact I don't think it uses it) so one of the mk3 drivers should work fine for that.

remixed_from.author: EliteNetworks
remixed_from.title: Generic Item Holder for Whirlpool Gladiator Track

description.text:
The base track piece fits in the track and is easy to install and remove. It is strong enough for any type of hook.  
So far, the "S" hook needs something else to be useful, not sure what to do for it yet. However, everything else works as intended.  More accessories are on the way.   
For production, use a dot of super glue to keep the base and attachment from sliding on each other.

06-12-15 Fixed default orientation of basket
07-17-15 Added V3 Loop kit in correct orientation
07-30-15 Added V7 of the base, now 1 solid body
02-06-16 Fixed basket, didn't lay flay on print bed

IMPORTANT PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS  
ABS Tends to need a raft for me (for small parts), but PLA sticks to the glass better.  
No Supports needed unless specified:  
Base Mount:  20% fill, ABS or PLA, both tested fine. The rest of this section handles exceptions to the default or norm.  
Mini loop hook:  Position on back so loops are UP, no support needed.  Choose density appropriate to weight of intended use. V1 is for light use, V3 is much stronger, but uses more material.  
S-Hook:  Failed proof of concept, needs something else to be useful.  I may revisit this later.  I don't recommend printing S hook..  
BASKET: Fixed so there is nothing special, just print it.  Takes 6 hours for me.

comments.text: I used your base mount to adopt FrankLumien's Screwdriver holder to the Gladiator system in a remix.  Gave  your props there, but figured I would drop back in and say thanks!  Thanks for designing this system!

description.text: The Carew in your car

comments.text: Encourage poor aero design if you like, makes no difference to me.
comments.author: DGA

comments.text: You DO know that a vortex generator has to have sharp edges, and has to be misaligned to the normal airflow, don't you? Otherwise it's just drag without any boundary layer turbulence.
comments.author: DGA

comments.text:
I think you're giving the creator an unnecessarily hard time here.
A boundary layer can also be tripped by intermixing the lower velocity layers closer to the surface with the higher velocity layers further out, which this design will likely achieve. Sharp edges can make a difference for the extent and quality of the vortices, but the Reynolds number also has an effect on that. I don't see why it would have to be misaligned to the normal airflow.
So in order to give constructive criticism on how to improve this design, you should be more polite and explain better on how to solve the problems you pointed out.
comments.author: DGA

title: WD Extruder for Qu-Bd OneUp TwoUp and others

description.text:
Wanted to replace the current extruder with a more open design and turned 90 degrees. Working great.
Video in action https://youtu.be/UUGyNforwh4
Using original brass gear - https://youtu.be/gmL29dGagAo Credits:
E3D Hotend Model - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341689
Basic Extruder - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:183982
Carriage Mount - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:408818
Nema 17 Model - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67561
E3D Mount - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512452

Update: The extruder will print without any supports but may need to be rotated. The part that attaches to the x-mount should be laying flat. Print out one of each. Use various M3 nuts and bolts. Good idea is to seat the nuts before assembling anything. Uses 608zz skateboard bearing and M8 gear. Should work with most any gear driver and bearing. Check out the pics for how to press the bearing rod into the bearing. Metric bolt source http://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com/index.php?PHPSESSID=-0pPdMw,AdTgXR3IT14jy0
thanks to http://www.fabric8r.com/forums/showthread.php?2454-Metric-bolts-nuts-Source-in-US&p=23873&viewfull=1#post23873

  • Panel mounting 20mm fuse holder (Farnell 963-0198)
  • Arcoelectric H8553VBNAO illuminated mains switch (Farnell 150388)

This bike is modeled on a bike seen all around our cities (Dubin, Cork, Limerick, Galway - Ireland), and is part of a new bike share initiative by our National Transport Authority in partnership with City Councils (www.bikeshare.ie)
The printable bike shared here, has a blank tab that you can add a club or voluntary group name to if you wish, as a printable give-away gimmick. Example also included in the file for our Maker group. (Sketchup file shared for ease of modification) The design is derived from "Touring Bike Business Card", but is sadly no longer business card size.

The single STL prints well when sliced at .2mm layer height.
To achieve the two colour look on the bike, I changed the filament from black to red after layer 5, simply printing the raised surfaces in a different colour (Red). Depending on your printer you will have to experiment with when and how you change colour.
(the files are not designed specifically for dual nozzle printers) The exported STL from Sketchup was repaired via Netfabb, hence the "_fixed" in their names. If you add your name or logo to the tab in the Sketchup file, and export to STL I'd recommend you process via Netfabb Cloud repair for best slicing results later. The bike bits should click together easily and stay together without glue, but the experience may be printer/print quality dependent. The assembly instructions will resemble those from which the bike was derived... assembly instruction visible here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:714484/#files
Enjoy!

title: Joytech eCom Mouthpiece (Mundstück)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Thats how you can repair a broken eCom Mouthpiece
I use Bendlay i hope it is healthier.

• Place broken Mouthpiece with cracks on printbed and heat it up
    to 140°C (with the metal Piece on the bottom )
  • Take a pliers and pull the Metal part out of the broken
    Mouthpiece. Watch out HOT !
  • Print the new one (Needs a lot time for slicing , use mid Resolution for shorter slicing )
  • Use some force to place the metal part in the new Printed
    Mouthpiece

• Gerissenes Mundstück mit dem Gewinde nach unten auf das
    beheizbare Druckbett legen und auf 140°C aufheizen.
  • Eine Zange nehmen um das Metallstück raus zu ziehen. Vorsicht Heiß !
  • Neues Mundstück drucken
  • Mundstück mit etwas Gewallt auf das Metallteil stecken .

author: hgerwin

title: Phone stand for Galaxy Note 3, no case

description.text:
***Updated the top section to be thicker as someone complained about breakage. Also I recommend using a USB micro cable as the full cables aren't very flexible and can cause the stand to tip over. I prefer this phone orientation and simply don't want to increase the base size 4-6" to accommodate the radius needed to avoid that.
Created this stand for my Note 3. Phone just slides in and out - full screen and all buttons should be fully accessible. Printed in ABS at .3 layer height at 50% infill with 3 perimeters to keep the top section strong. Cable routing should accommodate a full USB 3 cable which can be quite burly. That is also the reason the base is quite thick (radius of bend of thick USB 3 cables).

comments.text: I have been using mine almost daily for 4 months with no breakage... printed in ABS. I ended up using a USB micro cable though.
